elements.content: Self-assembly reactions of silver(I) nitrate with 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) as a main ligand and linker, and various benzenecarboxylic acids [benzoic (Hba), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba), or terephthalic (H2tpa) acid] as ancillary ligand sources, provide the first general synthetic entry toward the controlled N,P-coordination mode of PTA, giving rise to the new series of coordination polymers [Ag(ba)(μ-PTA)] n (1), [Ag(μ-cba)(μ-PTA)] n ·5nH2O (2), [Ag(μ-aba)(μ-PTA)] n ·3nH2O (3), and [Ag2(μ4-tpa)(μ-PTA)2] n ·2nH2O (4). They have been isolated as air- and light-stable crystalline solids, characterized by IR and NMR spectroscopies, and elemental and single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, which feature the generation of infinite PTA-driven 1D or 2D metal−organic networks composed of various Ag-benzenecarboxylate nodes and PTA linkers. A crucial synthetic and architectural defining role is played by the ancillary benzenecarboxylate ligand, a slight modification of which allows design of topologically distinct coordination networks that vary from 1D zigzag (in 1), ladder-like (in 2), and tubular-like (in 3) chains to 2D gridlike undulating nets (in 4). Weak agostic interactions are observed between the CH groups of the ancillary ligands (in 1) or the methylene groups of PTA (in 2 and 4) and the silver(I) center. The metal−organic chains of 2 and 3 also act as host matrices for intercalated guest water molecules, which are associated by multiple H-bonds into infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n wavelike layers (in 2) or discrete (H2O)3 clusters (in 3), resulting also in further extension of silver−organic hosts to 3D supramolecular frameworks. Compounds 1−4 widen the very limited family of PTA-driven coordination polymers, representing also the first heteroligand coordination compounds that simultaneously bear PTA and carboxylate ligands.

Weak agostic interactions are observed between the CH groups of the ancillary ligands (in 1) or the methylene groups of PTA (in 2 and 4) and the silver(I) center. The metal-organic chains of 2 and 3 also act as host matrices for intercalated guest water molecules, which are associated by multiple H-bonds into infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n  wavelike layers (in 2) or discrete (H2O)3 clusters (in 3), resulting also in further extension of silver-organic hosts to 3D supramolecular frameworks. elements.content: A new series of topologically distinct PTA-driven frameworks has been easily generated by self-assembly, providing the first general synthetic entry toward the controlled N,P-coordination mode of PTA and thus opening up its still unexplored use in crystal engineering.

elements.content: Within the sweeping development of crystal engineering, the design of new coordination polymers (or metal−organic frameworks) is nowadays a very popular research direction, attracting increased attention in view of the structural diversity and the variety of unusual properties of such metal−organic materials. Although many types of coordination networks have been constructed from metal−organic building blocks (nodes) and various organic linkers, most of the latter are typically based on N- and/or O-donor organic ligands (e.g., different diamine, polypyridine, and polycarboxylate derivatives). In contrast, the application of P- and N,P-type phosphine linkers remains poorly explored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Within the sweeping development of crystal engineering, the design of new coordination polymers (or metal-organic frameworks) is nowadays a very popular research direction, attracting increased attention in view of the structural diversity and the variety of unusual properties of such metal-organic materials. Although many types of coordination networks have been constructed from metal-organic building blocks (nodes) and various organic linkers, most of the latter are typically based on N- and/or O-donor organic ligands (e.g., different diamine, polypyridine, and polycarboxylate derivatives). In contrast, the application of P- and N,P-type phosphine linkers remains poorly explored.

elements.content: In recent years, the water-soluble cagelike aminophosphine 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) has become one of the most relevant ligands in aqueous organometallic chemistry, which is broadly used for the synthesis of metal complexes with recognized applications in different areas. However, in spite of the potential availability of up to four coordination sites and its hexagonal diamandoid-like geometry, PTA has not yet found a noteworthy application in the design of coordination networks, since it almost exclusively adopts the monodentate P-coordination in the vast majority of known compounds. Although some very rare coordination polymers with PTA acting in an unconventional N,P- or N,N,P-coordination mode have been recently reported, namely including 1D Ru/Ag, Ru/Au, and Cu chains, and 2D Ag layers, all these compounds were obtained only as single examples, thus suggesting an accidental character of the observed multiple coordination of the PTA cage. Besides, any guidelines and/or generalized synthetic procedures to engineer coordination polymers through a controlled N,P-coordination of PTA remain virtually unknown. Hence, the development of a procedure for the rational design of diverse PTA-driven metal−organic networks constitutes a main objective of the present work.

However, in spite of the potential availability of up to four coordination sites and its hexagonal diamandoid-like geometry, PTA has not yet found a noteworthy application in the design of coordination networks, since it almost exclusively adopts the monodentate P-coordination in the vast majority of known compounds. Although some very rare coordination polymers with PTA acting in an unconventional N,P- or N,N,P-coordination mode have been recently reported, namely including 1D Ru/Ag, Ru/Au, and Cu chains, and 2D Ag layers, all these compounds were obtained only as single examples, thus suggesting an accidental character of the observed multiple coordination of the PTA cage. Besides, any guidelines and/or generalized synthetic procedures to engineer coordination polymers through a controlled N,P-coordination of PTA remain virtually unknown. Hence, the development of a procedure for the rational design of diverse PTA-driven metal-organic networks constitutes a main objective of the present work.

elements.content: Following our general research lines on the self-assembly synthesis of copper−organic frameworks and on the coordination chemistry of PTA and derivatives, we have recently reported the first Cu coordination polymer [Cu(μ-N3)(μ-PTA)] n derived from PTA. As an extension of these studies toward a rational design of PTA-driven coordination networks, we have focused our attention on silver(I) due to (i) its coordination versatility and a recognized use in the construction of a high diversity of framework materials and (ii) known examples of Ag(I)-PTA polymers.

As an extension of these studies toward a rational design of PTA-driven coordination networks, we have focused our attention on silver(I) due to (i) its coordination versatility and a recognized use in the construction of a high diversity of framework materials and (ii) known examples of Ag(I)-PTA polymers.

elements.content: Hence, we report herein an easy and versatile synthetic procedure that allows design of, for the first time, a diversity of metal coordination polymers through a controlled N,P-coordination mode of PTA linkers. The work also describes how a slight modification of an ancillary benzenecarboxylate ligand (L) leads to the self-assembly generation of four distinct silver(I) coordination polymers 1−4 having the general simplified formulas [Ag(L)(μ-PTA)] n ·n(H2O) x [L = benzoate, 4-cyanobenzoate, 2-aminobenzoate, or terephthalate (half molecule); x = 0−5], whose X-ray crystal structures feature the 1D zigzag (1), ladder-like (2), and tubular-like (3) chains, or 2D gridlike undulating nets (4). All compounds have been fully characterized, including by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and they appear to represent (i) the first series of coordination polymers generated thorough a controlled N,P-coordination of PTA and (ii) the first metal PTA derivatives bearing a carboxylate ligand.

Infrared spectra (4000−400 cm−1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX and Bruker IFS 1113v instrument in KBr pellets (abbreviations: vs, very strong; s, strong; m, medium; w, weak; br, broad; sh, shoulder). 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker 300 AMX spectrometer at ambient temperature. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All synthetic work was performed in air. All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used as received, except 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA), which was prepared by a published method. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX and Bruker IFS 1113v instrument in KBr pellets (abbreviations: vs, very strong; s, strong; m, medium; w, weak; br, broad; sh, shoulder). 1H and 31P{1H} NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker 300 AMX spectrometer at ambient temperature. The NMR spectra of 2-4 were run in DMSO-d 6 solutions in the presence of a trace amount of sodium deuteroxide (NaOD) to increase the solubility of the samples. The 31P chemical shifts are relative to an external 85% H3PO4 aqueous solution.

elements.content: Silver nitrate (0.2 mmol, 34 mg), PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg), and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, 0.2 mmol, 24 mg), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, 0.2 mmol, 29 mg), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, 0.2 mmol, 27 mg) or terephthalic (H2tpa, 0.1 mmol, 17 mg) for 1, 2, 3, or 4, respectively] were combined in a solution containing MeOH (5 mL), CH2Cl2 (5 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred with heating (ca. 50 °C) for 30 min to produce a white suspension, which was subjected to a dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M solution of NH4OH (ca. 0.5 mL, until pH ≈ 8.5); then it was filtered off and dried in air to furnish compounds 1−4 as microcrystalline colorless solids. The obtained filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at room temperature, leading to a second half of 1−4 (including X-ray quality crystals); the total yield is ca. 50% based on silver nitrate.
elements.clean_text:
General Synthetic Procedure for 1-4 

Silver nitrate (0.2 mmol, 34 mg), PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg), and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, 0.2 mmol, 24 mg), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, 0.2 mmol, 29 mg), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, 0.2 mmol, 27 mg) or terephthalic (H2tpa, 0.1 mmol, 17 mg) for 1, 2, 3, or 4, respectively] were combined in a solution containing MeOH (5 mL), CH2Cl2 (5 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred with heating (ca. 50 °C) for 30 min to produce a white suspension, which was subjected to a dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M solution of NH4OH (ca. 0.5 mL, until pH ~ 8.5); then it was filtered off and dried in air to furnish compounds 1-4 as microcrystalline colorless solids. The obtained filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at room temperature, leading to a second half of 1-4 (including X-ray quality crystals); the total yield is ca. 50% based on silver nitrate.

The X-ray diffraction data of 1−4 were collected using a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Data were collected using omega scans of 0.5° per frame, and a full sphere of data was obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 package and refined with SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed with the WinGX System-Version 1.80.03. All hydrogens were inserted in calculated positions. Mercury, Diamond, and UCSF Chimera software packages were used for structural visualization. Crystal data and details of data collection for 1−4 are reported in Table .

Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 package and refined with SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed with the WinGX System-Version 1.80.03. As was mentioned above, there is no general route for the synthesis of coordination polymers wherein PTA acts as a linker, since all the previously reported framework compounds bearing PTA were obtained accidentally as single examples. Among them, there are two silver containing networks, namely a heterometallic Ru/Ag 1D [{CpRu(μ-PTA)2(DMSO)}{AgCl2}] (P- and N-coordination of PTA to Ru and Ag, respectively) polymer and a homometallic 2D [Ag(μ-PTA)(H2O)]NO3 (N,N,P-coordination of PTA to Ag) polymer. They have been synthesized by reacting (i) [CpRuCl(PTA)2] (Cp = cyclopentadienyl) with silver(I) triflate and ammonium chloride in DMSO, and (ii) AgNO3 with PTA in water.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectroscopic Characterization

As was mentioned above, there is no general route for the synthesis of coordination polymers wherein PTA acts as a linker, since all the previously reported framework compounds bearing PTA were obtained accidentally as single examples. Among them, there are two silver containing networks, namely a heterometallic Ru/Ag 1D [{CpRu(μ-PTA)2(DMSO)}{AgCl2}] (P- and N-coordination of PTA to Ru and Ag, respectively) polymer and a homometallic 2D [Ag(μ-PTA)(H2O)]NO3 (N,N,P-coordination of PTA to Ag) polymer. They have been synthesized by reacting (i) [CpRuCl(PTA)2] (Cp = cyclopentadienyl) with silver(I) triflate and ammonium chloride in DMSO, and (ii) AgNO3 with PTA in water.

elements.content: Aiming at the design of distinct coordination polymers through a general synthetic procedure, we directed our attention to the fact that Ag(I) ions possess a recognized ability to bind a vast variety of carboxylate ligands, often resulting in the generation of different silver−organic frameworks. In fact, hexamethylenetetramine (the all-nitrogen analogue of PTA) was proven to be capable of connecting various Ag-carboxylate moieties. Bearing these features in mind and following our prior background on the self-assembly synthesis of coordination and supramolecular networks employing different benzenecarboxylate building blocks, we have attempted the generation of silver(I) coordination polymers from various Ag-carboxylate nodes and PTA linkers.
elements.clean_text: Aiming at the design of distinct coordination polymers through a general synthetic procedure, we directed our attention to the fact that Ag(I) ions possess a recognized ability to bind a vast variety of carboxylate ligands, often resulting in the generation of different silver-organic frameworks. In fact, hexamethylenetetramine (the all-nitrogen analogue of PTA) was proven to be capable of connecting various Ag-carboxylate moieties. Bearing these features in mind and following our prior background on the self-assembly synthesis of coordination and supramolecular networks employing different benzenecarboxylate building blocks, we have attempted the generation of silver(I) coordination polymers from various Ag-carboxylate nodes and PTA linkers.

elements.content: Hence, the reaction of silver(I) nitrate as a metal source with PTA as a main ligand and linker, and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, for 1), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, for 2), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, for 3), or terephthalic (H2tpa, for 4) acid] as an ancillary ligand source, in equimolar amounts at 50 °C in MeOH/CH2Cl2/H2O medium, followed by the alkalization with aqueous NH4OH, results in the self-assembly generation of the four new coordination polymers [Ag(ba)(μ-PTA)] n (1), [Ag(μ-cba)(μ-PTA)] n ·5nH2O (2), [Ag(μ-aba)(μ-PTA)] n ·3nH2O (3), and [Ag2(μ4-tpa)(μ-PTA)2] n ·2nH2O (4) (Scheme ). These products were isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on silver nitrate) and characterized by IR, 1H, and 31P NMR spectroscopies and elemental and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Compounds 1−4 are weakly soluble in polar solvents such as acetonitrile, DMSO, and water; however, their solubility increases in the presence of a trace amount of a base such as sodium hydroxide. One should also mention that the formation of the byproduct [Ag(μ-PTA)(H2O)] n (NO3) n has been observed in some cases.
elements.clean_text: Hence, the reaction of silver(I) nitrate as a metal source with PTA as a main ligand and linker, and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, for 1), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, for 2), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, for 3), or terephthalic (H2tpa, for 4) acid] as an ancillary ligand source, in equimolar amounts at 50 °C in MeOH/CH2Cl2/H2O medium, followed by the alkalization with aqueous NH4OH, results in the self-assembly generation of the four new coordination polymers [Ag(ba)(μ-PTA)] n  (1), [Ag(μ-cba)(μ-PTA)] n ⋅5nH2O (2), [Ag(μ-aba)(μ-PTA)] n ⋅3nH2O (3), and [Ag2(μ4-tpa)(μ-PTA)2] n ⋅2nH2O (4) (Scheme ). These products were isolated as air- and light-stable colorless microcrystalline solids in ca. 50% yields (based on silver nitrate) and characterized by IR, 1H, and 31P NMR spectroscopies and elemental and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Compounds 1-4 are weakly soluble in polar solvents such as acetonitrile, DMSO, and water; however, their solubility increases in the presence of a trace amount of a base such as sodium hydroxide. One should also mention that the formation of the byproduct [Ag(μ-PTA)(H2O)] n (NO3) n   has been observed in some cases.

elements.content:
Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulas of Coordination Polymers <bold>1</bold>−<bold>4</bold> <xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) P- and (2) N-coordination of PTA, (3) O-coordination of benzenecarboxylate, and (4) N-coordination of the NH2 group (in 3). Abbreviations: benzoic (Hba), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba), or terephthalic (H2tpa) acid. The scheme also shows how a slight modification of this acid (ancillary ligand source) leads to structurally distinct compounds.

elements.content: Apart from benzoic acid, the choice of Hcba, Haba, and H2tpa as ancillary ligand sources was governed by the presence of different functional groups (i.e., −CN, −NH2, and −COO, respectively) that can potentially provide an extra coordination to Ag, thus affecting the topology of the resulting network. In fact, such a modification of the benzenecarboxylate ligand gave rise to the formation of topologically distinct 1D (1−3) and 2D (4) coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Apart from benzoic acid, the choice of Hcba, Haba, and H2tpa as ancillary ligand sources was governed by the presence of different functional groups (i.e., -CN, -NH2, and -COO, respectively) that can potentially provide an extra coordination to Ag, thus affecting the topology of the resulting network. In fact, such a modification of the benzenecarboxylate ligand gave rise to the formation of topologically distinct 1D (1-3) and 2D (4) coordination polymers.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1−4 exhibit related features with typical vibrations due to the benzenecarboxylate and PTA ligands, as well as crystallization water molecules (in 2−4). Hence, v(H2O) vibrations are observed as one (in 4) or two (in 2 and 3) bands with maxima in the 3530−3200 cm−1 range, whose broad character is associated with extensive H-bonding interactions. In 3, one of these bands (3329 cm−1) can also be ascribed to v(NH2) vibrations. In addition, the less intense bands at 1655 (2), 1638 (3), or 1628 (4) cm−1 correspond to δ(H2O) vibrations. Several bands due to νas and νs(CH) are also detected in the 2950−2850 cm−1 range. In all compounds, two sets of high intensity vibrations are observed in the 1610−1535 and 1450−1375 cm−1 ranges due to the asymmetric and symmetric modes of the carboxylate groups, respectively. Besides, a weak ν(CN) band of the 4-cyanobenzoate moiety was detected at 2232 cm−1 in the spectrum of 2. The spectra of all compounds also feature a number of characteristic bands (1100−900 cm−1) associated with ν(C−X) (X = N, P) vibrations within the PTA ligands. The elemental analyses of 1−4 attest their analytical purity and are consistent with the formulations (Scheme ) authenticated by X-ray crystallography, as indicated below.

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectra of compounds 1−4 show two types of methylene protons in the PTA region. One of them, P−CH2−N, occurs as a singlet at δ 4.15 in 4 or a doublet at δ 4.17−4.27 in 1−3 with the respective 2 J(PH) values of 4.2, 2.7, and 2.3 Hz, which are rather low in comparison with that of 10.5 Hz in the uncoordinated PTA. The second type of methylene protons, N−CH2−N, displays an AB spin system centered at δ 4.45−4.58 that is assigned to the N−CHax−N and the N−CHeq−N protons, as reported in other cases. In the aromatic region, the 1H NMR spectra of 1−4 also exhibit appropriate resonances due to phenyl rings of the ba, cba, aba, and tpa anions coordinated to silver(I). In addition, a broad singlet ascribed to the NH2 protons of 2-aminobenzoate is observed at δ 6.70 in the spectrum of 3. The 31P{1H} NMR spectra are typical for silver monophosphine complexes, showing the corresponding broad singlets in the δ range from −82.9 to −85.4. The 107Ag−31P and 109Ag−31P spin−spin coupling was not observed in all cases due to the fast ligand exchange. In general, the NMR data support the preservation of the coordination environments around Ag(I) atoms upon dissolution in H2O (1) or DMSO (2−4).

elements.content: Although PTA adopts a P,N-coordination and acts as a linker in all four compounds, their main architectural distinctive features arise from the differences in Ag-carboxylate building blocks (nodes). Hence, the crystal structures of coordination polymers 1−4 reveal 1D infinite zigzag (1), ladder-like (2), and tubular-like (3) chains or 2D gridlike nets (4). The structures of 1−4, including ellipsoid plots and representations of polymeric networks, are depicted in Figures − , respectively. The selected bonding parameters are collected in Table , while the H-bond distances are given in Table . Additional crystal packing diagrams of 1−4 showing the relative spatial arrangement of adjacent 1D chains or 2D layers, as well as H-bonding interactions, are represented in Figures S1−S6 (). All the symmetry codes in the discussion below are those of Tables and .
elements.clean_text:
Basic Description of X-ray Crystal Structures

Although PTA adopts a P,N-coordination and acts as a linker in all four compounds, their main architectural distinctive features arise from the differences in Ag-carboxylate building blocks (nodes). Hence, the crystal structures of coordination polymers 1-4 reveal 1D infinite zigzag (1), ladder-like (2), and tubular-like (3) chains or 2D gridlike nets (4). The structures of 1-4, including ellipsoid plots and representations of polymeric networks, are depicted in Figures -  , respectively. The selected bonding parameters are collected in Table , while the H-bond distances are given in Table . Additional crystal packing diagrams of 1-4 showing the relative spatial arrangement of adjacent 1D chains or 2D layers, as well as H-bonding interactions, are represented in Figures S1-S6 (). All the symmetry codes in the discussion below are those of Tables  and .

The crystal structure of 1 is composed of symmetry generated Ag-benzoate blocks and μ-PTA linkers that adopt alternating P- or N-coordination, thus resulting in the generation of infinite 1D zigzag chains with the repeating period of 6.8475(4) Å (Figure ). The tricoordinated Ag1 atoms exhibit a distorted trigonal geometry filled by the P1 [2.3242(9) Å] and N11i [2.474(2) Å] atoms of PTA and the O1 [2.172(2) Å] atom of a monodentate benzoate ligand. The bond angles around Ag1 vary from 93.11(8) [O1−Ag1−N11i] to 111.82(6) [P1−Ag1−N11i] and 152.63(6)° [O1−Ag1−P1], suggesting a T-shaped coordination geometry around the Ag1 atoms. The crystal packing diagram of 1 () reveals that the neighboring 1D chains run down the a axis, with the shortest interchain Ag···Ag separation of 6.4282(5) Å.

elements.content: Although the asymmetric unit of 2 also bears one Ag atom, one carboxylate ligand, and one PTA linker (Figure a), the main difference in comparison with 1 arises from the μ-COO bridging mode of 4-cyanobenzoate, which results in the generation of disilver(I) [Ag2(μ-cba)2] nodes. They are doubly bound with μ-PTA linkers, furnishing an infinite 1D ladder-like double chain (Figure b and c) with the repeating period of 6.9214(5) Å equal to the a unit cell dimension (Table ). This double chain comprises cavities formed by repeating 12-membered ∼Ag2(μ-O)2-PTA-Ag2(μ-O)2-PTA∼ rings through the connective P1−Ag1−O1i [134.21(6)°] and O1i−Ag1−N11iii [98.96(8)°] angles. The coordination environment of each tetracoordinated Ag1 atom is occupied by two alternately P- and N-coordinated μ-PTA ligands [Ag1−P1 2.3282(8), Ag1−N11iii 2.368(2) Å] and two μ-cba moieties [Ag1−O1i 2.332(2) Å], arranged in a significantly distorted tetrahedral geometry with the bond angles [avg 106.40°] ranging from 84.35(8) to 134.21(6)° (Table ). The squarelike [Ag2(μ-O)2] cores are planar and possess the Ag···Agi and O1···O1i separations of 3.5699(4) and 3.436(3) Å, respectively. As in 1, the cagelike geometry of PTA is almost unaffected by the unusual N,P-coordination mode, with bonding parameters comparable to those of 1 and other Ag-PTA derivatives.

elements.content: In contrast to zigzag and ladder-like chains of 1 and 2, the crystal structure of 3 (Figure ) features a different architecture of an infinite 1D coordination network, owing to the presence of 2-aminobenzoate ligands. Being simultaneously coordinated to two symmetry generated Ag1 atoms through carboxylate and amino groups, the latter act as connectors between the adjacent ∼Ag-PTA-Ag-PTA∼ motifs, thus giving rise to the generation of 1D tubular-like chains (Figure b and c). The Ag1 atoms adopt a rather distorted tetrahedral coordination environment filled by the P1 [2.359(2) Å] and N11ii [2.541(6) Å] atoms from the two adjacent PTA linkers and the O1 [2.270(5) Å] and N1i [2.519(6) Å] atoms of O,N-coordinated μ-aba moieties (Figure a). The average bond angle around the Ag1 atoms is 108.3(2)°, while the major deviations from the idealized tetrahedral geometry concern the O1−Ag1−P1 [147.58(14)°] and O1−Ag1−N11ii [86.56(19)°] angles (Table ). The 1D chains in 3 can also be described as a repeating combination of tetrasilver [Ag4(μ-aba)3(μ-PTA)2]+ blocks, wherein the shortest Ag1···Ag1iii (linkage via aba) and Ag1···Ag1iv (linkage via PTA) separations are respectively 5.9796(11) and 6.8977(12) Å, with the latter value being equal to the a unit cell dimension. The 1D tubular-like chains are further stabilized by two intramolecular N1−H1B···O1 [2.796(8) Å] and N1−H1A···O2iv [2.939(8) Å] hydrogen bonds between NH2 and COO groups of 2-aminobenzoate moieties ( and Table ).

The average bond angle around the Ag1 atoms is 108.3(2)°, while the major deviations from the idealized tetrahedral geometry concern the O1-Ag1-P1 [147.58(14)°] and O1-Ag1-N11ii [86.56(19)°] angles (Table ). The 1D chains in 3 can also be described as a repeating combination of tetrasilver [Ag4(μ-aba)3(μ-PTA)2]+ blocks, wherein the shortest Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1iii (linkage via aba) and Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1iv (linkage via PTA) separations are respectively 5.9796(11) and 6.8977(12) Å, with the latter value being equal to the a unit cell dimension. The 1D tubular-like chains are further stabilized by two intramolecular N1-H1B⋅⋅⋅O1 [2.796(8) Å] and N1-H1A⋅⋅⋅O2iv [2.939(8) Å] hydrogen bonds between NH2 and COO groups of 2-aminobenzoate moieties ( and Table ).

elements.content: The molecular structure of 4 (Figure ) reveals some common features to those of 2, namely the presence of double chain motifs composed of planar [Ag2(μ-O)2] cores and μ-PTA linkers, as well as similar bonding parameters (Table ) and the tetrahedral geometry around the Ag1 centers. However, in contrast to 2, the dicarboxylate μ4-tpa ligands in 4 not only provide the sewage of Ag1 atoms into disilver(I) cores but also act as molecular pillars between neigboring 1D ladders, thus generating infinite 2D gridlike nets (Figure d). Hence, each of the μ4-terephthalate(4-) pillars simultaneously connect to four Ag1 atoms through two types of Ag1−O1(O1i) bonds [2.4316(15) and 2.2840(15) Å]. The resulting 2D net can be described as a collection of two types of cross-linking polymeric motifs: ∼Ag2(μ-O)2-(PTA)2-Ag2(μ-O)2-(PTA)2∼ and ∼Ag2(μ-O)2-(tpa)2-Ag2(μ-O)2-(tpa)2∼ with repeating periods (Ag···Ag separations) of 6.9593(3) and 9.8142(5) Å, respectively, which are equal to the a and b unit cell dimensions. As can be seen in Figure b, the 2D gridlike net possesses an undulating shape and features the presence of two types of cavities formed by repeating 12- [∼Ag2(μ-O)2-PTA-Ag2(μ-O)2-PTA∼] and 26-membered [∼Ag-PTA-Ag-tpa-Ag-PTA-Ag-tpa∼] rings. As in 3, the reinforcement of 2D nets is also observed in 4 through two H-bonds of crystallization water molecules (O10) with COO groups of tpa [O10−H10B···O2iv 2.823(3) Å] and N13 atoms of PTA cages [O10−H10A···N13v 2.954(3) Å] (). The adjacent nets () are separated by 10.2972(5) Å, the distance equal to the c unit cell dimension.

elements.content: C−Hx···Ag interactions between the Ag metal ion and symmetry generated hydrogen atoms from aromatic (in 1, x = 6), PTA [in 2, x = 11B and 15B; in 4, x = 11A and 14B) or amine (in 3, x = 1A and 1B) groups were found. Such Ag···Hx bond distances range from 2.92 (in 1) to 3.09 Å (in 3). These values are somewhat longer than those found in the literature, although such examples are scarce. Medium intermolecular π···π stacking interactions involving the aromatic rings were found in 2 [centroid···centroid 3.6325(17) Å], whereas strong H···π interactions were detected in 1 and 3, always involving one methylene hydrogen from PTA and the benzene ring of the ancillary ligand [in 1, C15−H15A···centroid, 2.72 Å, 130.5°; in 3, C13−H13B···centroid, 2.553 Å, 161.65°]. In 2 and 4, remarkable contacts were detected between the Ag2O2 core and one or even two methylene hydrogens from PTA [in 2, C11−H11B···centroid, 2.63 Å, 107.33°; in 4, C11−H11A···centroid, 2.61 Å, 100.93° and C11−H11B···centroid, 2.89 Å, 84.54°].

elements.content: The classification and description of hydrogen-bonded water assemblies, trapped within crystal structures of various metal−organic materials, have attracted increased attention in recent years due to the relevance of this information for understanding the hydration phenomena in physical and materials chemistry, drug design and pharmacology, biochemistry, catalysis, and supramolecular chemistry. In pursuit of our interest in the identification and analysis of various water clusters and supramolecular assemblies driven by water molecules, within different metal−organic matrices, we have examined the multiple H-bonding interactions in the crystal structures of 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text:
Water Associates and Supramolecular Frameworks in 2 and 3 

The classification and description of hydrogen-bonded water assemblies, trapped within crystal structures of various metal-organic materials, have attracted increased attention in recent years due to the relevance of this information for understanding the hydration phenomena in physical and materials chemistry, drug design and pharmacology, biochemistry, catalysis, and supramolecular chemistry. In pursuit of our interest in the identification and analysis of various water clusters and supramolecular assemblies driven by water molecules, within different metal-organic matrices, we have examined the multiple H-bonding interactions in the crystal structures of 2 and 3.

elements.content: Hence, interesting features of 2 and 3 arise from the presence of five (in 2) or three (in 3) independent crystallization water molecules, which interact among themselves and with metal−organic 1D chains (hosts) via various intermolecular hydrogen bonds, involving also symmetry generated H2O molecules (Table ). Such extensive interactions give rise to the assembly of infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n layers in 2 (Figure a and b) and discrete (H2O)3 clusters in 3 (Figure c). These intercalated water aggregates (guests) play a key role in sewing the host metal−organic 1D chains into 3D supramolecular frameworks (Figures , ) by means of multiple H-bonds.

Such extensive interactions give rise to the assembly of infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n  layers in 2 (Figure a and b) and discrete (H2O)3 clusters in 3 (Figure c). These intercalated water aggregates (guests) play a key role in sewing the host metal-organic 1D chains into 3D supramolecular frameworks (Figures , ) by means of multiple H-bonds.

elements.content: As mentioned above, each polycyclic {(H2O)11} n layer is constructed from five independent H2O molecules (O10, O20, O30, O40, and O50), which are assembled into an infinite 2D network by means of seven different O−H···O interactions with O···O separations varying from 2.745(5) to 2.894(4) Å with an average value of 2.837(5) Å (Table ), which is comparable to that found in liquid water (i.e., 2.85 Å) and other compounds. The resulting network can be considered as a set of alternating 5- and 9-membered water rings (Figure a) that together form a larger bicyclic (H2O)11 ring. These rings are infinitely extended in two directions, thus furnishing a 2D layer with the L5(4)9(8) topology according to the systematization introduced by Infantes et al. The pentagon-like (H2O)5 rings are almost planar, while the (H2O)9 cycles are nonplanar and possess an intricate geometry, thus contributing to a relief wavelike architecture of a 2D layer (Figure b), which possesses repeating periods of 6.639(5) and 6.9214(5) Å. Interestingly, the latter value is equal to the repeating period of the metal−organic chains and the a unit cell dimension.
elements.clean_text:
Infinite 2D Water Layers in 2 

As mentioned above, each polycyclic {(H2O)11} n  layer is constructed from five independent H2O molecules (O10, O20, O30, O40, and O50), which are assembled into an infinite 2D network by means of seven different O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions with O⋅⋅⋅O separations varying from 2.745(5) to 2.894(4) Å with an average value of 2.837(5) Å (Table ), which is comparable to that found in liquid water (i.e., 2.85 Å) and other compounds. The resulting network can be considered as a set of alternating 5- and 9-membered water rings (Figure a) that together form a larger bicyclic (H2O)11 ring. These rings are infinitely extended in two directions, thus furnishing a 2D layer with the L5(4)9(8) topology according to the systematization introduced by Infantes et al. The pentagon-like (H2O)5 rings are almost planar, while the (H2O)9 cycles are nonplanar and possess an intricate geometry, thus contributing to a relief wavelike architecture of a 2D layer (Figure b), which possesses repeating periods of 6.639(5) and 6.9214(5) Å. Interestingly, the latter value is equal to the repeating period of the metal-organic chains and the a unit cell dimension.

elements.content: The infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n layers occupy voids between adjacent arrays of host silver−organic 1D chains, providing also their extension to the 3D supramolecular framework via repeating H-bonding interactions (Figures a, b). Hence, each of the clustered O10 water molecules acts as a H-bond donor to the N12 atoms of PTA [O10−H10B···N12vii, 2.767(4) Å], whereas both the O20 and O40 water molecules simultaneously link to the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2) of the cba moiety [O20−H20B···O2v, 2.921(4) Å; O40−H40B···O2v, 2.900(4) Å] (Table ).

Hence, each of the clustered O10 water molecules acts as a H-bond donor to the N12 atoms of PTA [O10-H10B⋅⋅⋅N12vii, 2.767(4) Å], whereas both the O20 and O40 water molecules simultaneously link to the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2) of the cba moiety [O20-H20B⋅⋅⋅O2v, 2.921(4) Å; O40-H40B⋅⋅⋅O2v, 2.900(4) Å] (Table ).

elements.content: Although the crystal structure of 3 also bears independent crystallization water molecules (O10, O20, O30), they are assembled to only discrete acyclic (H2O)3 clusters [O10−H10A···O30v 2.894(8) Å; O30−H30B···O20ii 2.747(9) Å; O10···O30···O20 106.1(2)°], which can be classified within the D3-type according to the above-mentioned systematization. As in 2, such guest (H2O)3 associates occupy voids in 3 and extensively interact via two repeating O−H···NPTA and two O−H···Oaba H-bonds (Table ) with host 1D tubular-like chains, sewing them together and forming a 3D supramolecular pattern (Figures b, c).
elements.clean_text:
Discrete Water Trimers in 3 

Although the crystal structure of 3 also bears independent crystallization water molecules (O10, O20, O30), they are assembled to only discrete acyclic (H2O)3 clusters [O10-H10A⋅⋅⋅O30v 2.894(8) Å; O30-H30B⋅⋅⋅O20ii 2.747(9) Å; O10⋅⋅⋅O30⋅⋅⋅O20 106.1(2)°], which can be classified within the D3-type according to the above-mentioned systematization. As in 2, such guest (H2O)3 associates occupy voids in 3 and extensively interact via two repeating O-H⋅⋅⋅NPTA and two O-H⋅⋅⋅Oaba H-bonds (Table ) with host 1D tubular-like chains, sewing them together and forming a 3D supramolecular pattern (Figures b, c).

elements.content: In the present work, we have opened up the use of the cagelike aminophosphine 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) as a convenient hexagonal diamandoid-like linker for the rationale design of metal−organic frameworks. As a result, four distinct silver(I) coordination polymers 1−4, constructed from various Ag-carboxylate nodes and PTA linkers, have been generated via an easy and versatile self-assembly synthetic procedure that allowed an unprecedented control of N,P-coordination of PTA. This route thus provides the first general synthetic entry to compounds bearing N,P-coordinated PTA species. A slight modification of the ancillary benzenecarboxylate ligand appears to provide a driving force in the formation of topologically distinct 1D and 2D coordination networks that range from infinite 1D zigzag (1), ladder-like (2), and tubular-like (3) chains to 2D gridlike undulating nets (4).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present work, we have opened up the use of the cagelike aminophosphine 1,3,5-triaza-7-phosphaadamantane (PTA) as a convenient hexagonal diamandoid-like linker for the rationale design of metal-organic frameworks. As a result, four distinct silver(I) coordination polymers 1-4, constructed from various Ag-carboxylate nodes and PTA linkers, have been generated via an easy and versatile self-assembly synthetic procedure that allowed an unprecedented control of N,P-coordination of PTA. This route thus provides the first general synthetic entry to compounds bearing N,P-coordinated PTA species. A slight modification of the ancillary benzenecarboxylate ligand appears to provide a driving force in the formation of topologically distinct 1D and 2D coordination networks that range from infinite 1D zigzag (1), ladder-like (2), and tubular-like (3) chains to 2D gridlike undulating nets (4).

elements.content: The study also shows that the PTA-driven metal−organic networks can constitute suitable matrices to host intercalated H-bonded water associates. In fact, the examination of the crystal structures of 2 and 3 led to the identification of infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n layers (in 2) or discrete water trimers (in 3) that play a key role toward the extension of 1D metal−organic chains to 3D supramolecular frameworks via multiple H-bonds. Hence, the work also widens the growing family of water clusters and assemblies identified in framework materials.
elements.clean_text: The study also shows that the PTA-driven metal-organic networks can constitute suitable matrices to host intercalated H-bonded water associates. In fact, the examination of the crystal structures of 2 and 3 led to the identification of infinite 2D {(H2O)11} n  layers (in 2) or discrete water trimers (in 3) that play a key role toward the extension of 1D metal-organic chains to 3D supramolecular frameworks via multiple H-bonds. Hence, the work also widens the growing family of water clusters and assemblies identified in framework materials.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is noteworthy to mention that 1−4 represent the first examples of heteroligand coordination compounds with PTA and its derivatives that also bear carboxylate moieties. In this regard, one should note that the coexistence of carboxylate O- with P- and N-donors at a common binding metal center is very unusual, not only among silver coordination polymers but also within any other transition metal frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, it is noteworthy to mention that 1-4 represent the first examples of heteroligand coordination compounds with PTA and its derivatives that also bear carboxylate moieties. In this regard, one should note that the coexistence of carboxylate O- with P- and N-donors at a common binding metal center is very unusual, not only among silver coordination polymers but also within any other transition metal frameworks.

elements.content: Besides, the work has extended the still limited application of N,P-aminophosphine linkers for the design of framework materials. Further research will be pursued toward the exploration of PTA cores in engineering different types of silver(I) coordination polymers with tunable topologies, including also the still unknown 3D PTA-driven frameworks.

cln_elements.content: Silver nitrate (0.2 mmol, 34 mg), PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg), and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, 0.2 mmol, 24 mg), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, 0.2 mmol, 29 mg), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, 0.2 mmol, 27 mg) or terephthalic (H2tpa, 0.1 mmol, 17 mg) for 1, 2, 3, or 4, respectively] were combined in a solution containing MeOH (5 mL), CH2Cl2 (5 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred with heating (ca. 50 °C) for 30 min to produce a white suspension, which was subjected to a dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M solution of NH4OH (ca. 0.5 mL, until pH ≈ 8.5); then it was filtered off and dried in air to furnish compounds 1−4 as microcrystalline colorless solids. The obtained filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at room temperature, leading to a second half of 1−4 (including X-ray quality crystals); the total yield is ca. 50% based on silver nitrate.
cln_elements.clean_text:
General Synthetic Procedure for 1-4 

Silver nitrate (0.2 mmol, 34 mg), PTA (0.2 mmol, 31 mg), and the corresponding carboxylic acid [benzoic (Hba, 0.2 mmol, 24 mg), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba, 0.2 mmol, 29 mg), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba, 0.2 mmol, 27 mg) or terephthalic (H2tpa, 0.1 mmol, 17 mg) for 1, 2, 3, or 4, respectively] were combined in a solution containing MeOH (5 mL), CH2Cl2 (5 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL). The obtained mixture was stirred with heating (ca. 50 °C) for 30 min to produce a white suspension, which was subjected to a dropwise addition of an aqueous 1 M solution of NH4OH (ca. 0.5 mL, until pH ~ 8.5); then it was filtered off and dried in air to furnish compounds 1-4 as microcrystalline colorless solids. The obtained filtrate was left in a vial to evaporate slowly in air at room temperature, leading to a second half of 1-4 (including X-ray quality crystals); the total yield is ca. 50% based on silver nitrate.

cln_elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 is composed of symmetry generated Ag-benzoate blocks and μ-PTA linkers that adopt alternating P- or N-coordination, thus resulting in the generation of infinite 1D zigzag chains with the repeating period of 6.8475(4) Å (Figure ). The tricoordinated Ag1 atoms exhibit a distorted trigonal geometry filled by the P1 [2.3242(9) Å] and N11i [2.474(2) Å] atoms of PTA and the O1 [2.172(2) Å] atom of a monodentate benzoate ligand. The bond angles around Ag1 vary from 93.11(8) [O1−Ag1−N11i] to 111.82(6) [P1−Ag1−N11i] and 152.63(6)° [O1−Ag1−P1], suggesting a T-shaped coordination geometry around the Ag1 atoms. The crystal packing diagram of 1 () reveals that the neighboring 1D chains run down the a axis, with the shortest interchain Ag···Ag separation of 6.4282(5) Å.

cln_elements.content:
Simplified Representation of Self-Assembly Syntheses with the Structural Formulas of Coordination Polymers <bold>1</bold>−<bold>4</bold> <xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 correspond to extensions of polymeric motifs via (1) P- and (2) N-coordination of PTA, (3) O-coordination of benzenecarboxylate, and (4) N-coordination of the NH2 group (in 3). Abbreviations: benzoic (Hba), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba), or terephthalic (H2tpa) acid. The scheme also shows how a slight modification of this acid (ancillary ligand source) leads to structurally distinct compounds.

Abbreviations: benzoic (Hba), 4-cyanobenzoic (Hcba), 2-aminobenzoic (Haba), or terephthalic (H2tpa) acid. The scheme also shows how a slight modification of this acid (ancillary ligand source) leads to structurally distinct compounds.
